security: The document contains discussions about intelligence operations, sources, and methods. Specifically, it mentions audiosurveillance operations, the use of U-2 flights over Cuba, and intelligence collection methods in Vietnam. Disclosing these details could compromise ongoing intelligence activities and reveal sensitive information about U.S. intelligence capabilities and sources. Directly quoting, "CIA has 100 agents reporting on Cuba; they report comprehensively but under difficult circumstances requiring resort to clandestine radio equipment and secret writing reports through the mails."
summary: Minutes from the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) meeting on October 1-2, 1964, covering topics such as audiosurveillance, Soviet satellite reconnaissance, the Tonkin Gulf incident, and intelligence briefings on various global hotspots.
summary_one_paragraph: This document presents the minutes of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board meeting held on October 1 and 2, 1964. The agenda included discussions on major board recommendations, audiosurveillance collection and countermeasures (specifically the U.S. Embassy in Moscow penetration), Soviet COSMOS satellite efforts, the recent Tonkin Gulf incident, and the alert warning and response capabilities of the U.S. intelligence community. The meeting also featured intelligence briefings on situations in South Vietnam, North Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Communist China, Malaysia-Indonesia, Cyprus, Congo, and Cuba, as well as discussions with the Director of Central Intelligence, John A. McCone.
title: Minutes of Board Meeting of October 1 and 2, 1964
